Entries.default: An elderly Roparu man squints in your direction before blinking profusely. He hobbles closer, bare feet slapping the splintered floorboards of his abode.
"I see much and many things. I simply do not... look with these eyes in the same manner that others do."
"Speak, and I will listen."
"I'm looking for a place called Delver's Row."
"Who are you?"
"Tell me about the Gullet. What's the history of this place?"
"Farewell."
"You mean the black market that lies nestled in the depths of the Narrows."
"I've lived for many years in this Gullet. My skin and bones have withered with each year, twisted harder, so that the Roparu now call me paki takiri."
"Both time and tragedy have rotted the Gullet into a place of filth and crowdedness."
"The guards do their best to stomp it out, but they are a single boot against a thousand ants."
"Though you can see I am not very big or much sturdy. If a dispute arises within the Gullet, I will see it resolved - that I can promise you."
"Once, we Roparu lived in a fine neck of the city. But that time has fallen and with it the ruins of our Old City under Neketaka."
"Long before the foreigners swarmed us, a sea quake rumbled our city, and the mountain cratered down."
"Many cried to Ondra and were swallowed for their efforts." His dead eyes flick side to side.
"Now the Mataru send us into the ruins of the Old City to be punished. Within that pit lies darkness and death. Not silence, but an end."
"I hear you."
The old man grimaces some attempt at a smile. He inclines his head to you, indicating he's aware of your presence.
The man's arms are thin as sticks. What teeth he has are yellowed or black from years of malnourishment.
"I was told you could tell me about the hunger problem in the Gullet."
"This is the Huana way: the fish of our nets are drawn for the tribe."
"The Dawnstars would feed us, but the guards forbid them to pervert the order of sharing."
"But for days now, we've had nothing."
"What happened?"

"Ulög was never late with his shipments, always very conscientious. A good boy.

"For him to disappear for several days without word... he must be dead."
"You mentioned that the Roparu are hurting?"
He peers steadily into your face, blinking faster all the while.
"Can you see me? How do you know who I am?"
[Say nothing.]
"People speak of your kindness, Watcher who chases Eothas."
"Many know you for your dark temperament, Watcher who chases Eothas."
"Footsteps like distant thunder. The wind whispers of a Watcher who chases Eothas."
"People speak of your kindness, Watcher who chases Eothas."
"People speak of your kindness, Watcher who chases Eothas."
"You have cut a rather fearsome reputation for yourself, Watcher who chases Eothas."
"The queen refuses to increase our share of the prize-share. Without Ulög's shipments, we will surely starve. I am asking you, what else can we do?"
"The Dawnstars sought to help you before. We can use them."
"I can re-establish the smuggling operation through the black market."
"Pitli is a Child of the Dawnstars and has become the Gullet's most cherished healer. I believe she would willingly hear your request for charity."
"You need an advocate. I will speak with the royals at Serpent's Crown on your behalf."
"Perhaps you can achieve what those of my caste cannot. Gain us favor with the crown, and always we Roparu will be indebted to you."
The Príncipi will supply food again if more Roparu work with them."
"The Dawnstars will share their crops, and the Príncipi will smuggle it in through Delver's Row."
"The queen will double her efforts to feed your growing population."
"The Dawnstars will share their crops, and the queen will allocate the majority for the Gullet."
"I've no choice but to hope this... venture together fares better than our last. We will accept the Príncipi's generosity and work to return it tenfold."
"Never can I thank you enough, Watcher who has the ear of both kith and gods. Always the Roparu will know of your kindness."
"I doubted the Dawnstars would work with criminals, but you have proved me wrong."
"Not in this lifetime could I have hoped for more - to have garnered our queen's generosity, I ache to believe it."
"I heard of missionaries distributing food throughout the Gullet, though I did not think it could be true."
[Say nothing.]
He rolls his dark eyes skyward. A sigh whistles between his teeth.
"Many know you for your dark temperament, Watcher who chases Eothas."
"You have cut a rather fearsome reputation for yourself, Watcher who chases Eothas."
"I can hear you breathing, boy."
"If you're saying the gods sent me, you're wrong."
"What's causing the Roparu such pain?"
"This place is a bit like an open wound. Couldn't hurt to clean it up."
[Shrug.]
"I also hear the Roparu's heartbeat - grown thready and pained. Now a Watcher comes to the Gullet, as Amira has shown me you would."
[Leave] "I'll think about it."
"The Roparu are being crushed from the top. We starve so slowly it is an agony."
"Either way, you do not work for free. Is that what you mean to say, boy?"
Entries.female: "Either way, you do not work for free. Is that what you mean to say, girl?"

Entries.default: He grimaces, baring jagged, gray-cast teeth.
"Boy, I can STILL hear you breathing."
Entries.female: "Girl, I can STILL hear you breathing."

Entries.default: [Leave.]
"I hear much and many things - like the footsteps of a god on the horizon."
With a stiff bow, the elder Roparu begs his leave.
"Actually, a starving beggar sent me to speak with you."
His lids half close, heavy with thought.
"I cannot fatten your coin purse, but the Roparu never forget a kindness. Do right by us, and all of Neketaka will speak your name."
"You have yourself a deal."
"I'll think about it. Maybe the gods will convince me to help you, after all."
"Since you neither speak nor slip away, perhaps you will listen."
"All spoils are gifted to the whole of the tribe. The tribe then partakes from the top down - from the most deserving to the least."
"Why are the Roparu the least deserving, the last to partake of the tribe's spoils?"
"Sounds like a terrible system."
"Of course, it makes the most sense."
"It is the way of life." He grates a hard sound from his throat.
"It is the way of life." He grates a hard sound from his throat.
"The Mataru risk their lives to protect the tribe. The Kuaru provided skilled goods and services."
"One came to us, lived with us awhile. But Pitli's dead."
The old man's eyes glisten.
The old man's eyes glisten.
"Starving... are the gods so occupied that they cannot see inside the mountain?"
The old man shrugs.
"No one deserves to suffer. Not like this."
Edér looks at you and takes in a deep breath, holding it and motioning for you to do the same.
"Now no breath but flapping arms from your companion. Is he soft of mind? You must be charitable to have taken him in."
"You got no idea." Xoti shakes her head.
Edér looks at you and takes in a deep breath, holding it and motioning for you to do the same.
"You got no idea." Xoti shakes her head.
"Now no breath but flapping arms from your companion. Is he soft of mind? You must be charitable to have taken him in."
"Them pox-riddled harbor hogs'd be better served taking towels to the sea, for all the drying they'd give it."
The old man nods.
"Onekaza will listen. Her concern holds this island together."
He cants his gaze to the side, eyes wandering.
"That is a fine idea! When it comes to mission-work, my brethren are always happy to help."
He cants his gaze to the side, eyes wandering.
"Some of the less crazy ones, hopefully."
"Makes me wonder what Rauatai can get out of this place if the locals can't even feed themselves."
"Ekera, one hopes it is a temporary solution."
"Hardly a perfect option, but perhaps the best available. I sympathize." He smiles wryly.
"Long as it doesn't end up going wrong for the same reasons."
"If legal markets cannot provide, illicit markets are the natural result."

"The starving sated and the pirates paid. Everyone's grins and giggles. Savvy play, cap, worthy of Remaro hisself."

Serafen smiles and pats his belly.
"I suppose this once... the ends justify the means."
He strokes the end of his chin.
"If the queen isn't feeding her people, I doubt some newcomer has the clout to change that."

"Watcher. Always, you are welcome here. I owe you much and more for your kindness."

The old man dips his head to you..
"How else can we resolve the food shortage?"
"If we cannot convince the Mataru nor the Príncipi, I believe the Dawnstars may help us."
"One came to us, lived with us awhile. But Pitli's dead."
"Pitli is a Child of the Dawnstars and has become the Gullet's most cherished healer. I believe she would willingly hear your request for charity."
"At least piety can thrive in this dark and unforgiving borough."
"That sea-swept voice... one of Ondra's own comes to visit me at last."
"Hmph. What say you, boy?"
"I have heard much, as well."
His dark eyes wander before landing at last on your face.
"The tribe takes care of the Roparu more than we contribute to the tribe. Or it did, before our numbers swelled too large."
"There was a man who helped us, a soft-hearted pirate named Ulög. He worked with a Príncipi captain - Mad Morena, they call her - to bring us food from the black market."
"Follow the path that Ulög first walked for us. But do not meet his same end."
"Should you need refuge within Neketaka, know that the Roparu will stand by your side."
"You must find Delver's Row, boy. They keep a lift that will take you down to where the pirates play. Surely you'll find Ulög's contact there."
Entries.female: "You must find Delver's Row, girl. They hide a lift that will take you down to where the pirates play. Surely you'll find Ulög's contact there."

Entries.default: "Perhaps the High Priestess would be willing to help us. She preaches at the Temple of Gaun in the Sacred Stair."
"Perhaps the High Priestess would be willing to help us. She preaches at the Temple of Gaun in the Sacred Stair."
"Yes, I know."
"The fruit of our fields, too, is reaped for the tribe, and the coin of our pockets belongs, not to one, but to all."
"As you know, the fish of our nets are drawn for the tribe."
"Of course." He smiles, showing discolored teeth.
"Do the Roparu not partake last in your tribe? For Kahanga, we do."
"I'm not interested in fame. What else can you offer me?"
"Before I agree to anything, I need information. How do I get to Delver's Row?"
"That, I do not know. Someone at The Hole may be able to tell you more."
"Indeed, you do not seem the type to value your name."
"Perhaps you prefer the weight of a fine sword in hand. Help us, Watcher, and I will tell you where to find one."
[Leave] "Your sob story isn't my problem. Find someone else."
"Wait!" He frantically grabs at your sleeve.
"Wait!" He frantically grabs at your sleeve.
"I cannot fatten your coin purse, but the Roparu never forget a kindness. Do right by us, and all of Neketaka will speak your name."
"I'm not interested in fame. What else can you offer me?"
"Tell me how to get to Delver's Row."
"That would do."
"Indeed, you do not seem the type to value your name."
"Perhaps you prefer the weight of a fine sword in hand. Help us, Watcher, and I will tell you where to find one."
"That, I do not know. Someone at The Hole may be able to tell you more."
"Then so it will be, so long as you aid us."
"Alright, I'll help you."
"Have a heart, boy - my people are dying! Is there nothing I can say to sway you?"
Entries.female: "Have a heart, girl - my people are dying! Is there nothing I can say to sway you?"

Entries.default: "Fine, I'll help you."
[Leave] "No. Farewell."
"I do not know how to get there, but someone at the tavern might."
"Amira bless you, Watcher."
"Take care, old man."
"Wait, you promised to tell me about a sword."
[Leave] "Farewell."
"May Amira's winds ever fill your sails, boy. We will not forget what you have done for us."
Entries.female: "May Amira's wind ever fill your sails, girl. We will not forget what you have done for us."

Entries.default: "So I did, so I did." He nods.
"Several months back, when the storm winds bellowed like the Beast of Winter himself, a woman appeared in the Gullet bearing a flaming sword."
"I listened uneasily as she paced the length of the bridge. She wept and raged, yelling sometimes at the sword and sometimes at Roparu nearby."

"At last she cried out and threw the sword from the bridge.

"It clattered down into the Old City below, where I presume it now rests."
"If you do not know your way to the Row, someone at The Hole maybe able to help you."
The old presses his palms together and nods.
"I found Ulög's body in the Narrows."
Enoi stills for a moment, only moving to blink his black pebble eyes. Then he takes a deep, shuddering breath and exhales all at once. His damp breath smells like bile and illness.
"It was as I feared, then. Tell me - how did he die? Was it fast, at least? Painless?"
"He was beaten to death. Looked like it went on a while before he died."
[Lie] "It was quick."
"He was beaten to death."
[Say nothing.]
[Lie] "All I found was a bundle of severed limbs and a note."
"The Gullet claims another life, then." The old man groans, rubbing his knobby-jointed fingers across his eyes.
"O-oh." A small whine escapes his throat. His hands tremble.
The old man's shoulders slump forward, and he heaves another shuddering sigh.
The old man's shoulders slump forward, and he heaves another shuddering sigh.
"I must think of something else to tell the people of the Gullet. That... that won't do." He shakes his head slowly.
"Thank you for your honesty, Watcher. Few are there who will deliver bad news in all its sorry truth."
"The Gullet claims another life, then." The old man groans, rubbing his knobby-jointed fingers across his eyes.
"I'm- I'm sorry you had to see that. It's not right."
"At least... at least he didn't suffer." He nods slowly.

"If the Mataru would only protect us as they ought to, our people wouldn't be prey to those crooks and cutthroat who prowl the Narrows like sharks."

Anger makes him shake.

"I see. I am to draw my own conclusions."

He rubs his knobby-knuckled fingers across his eyes. A shroud of exhaustion falls over him, and for a moment it seems as if he's done speaking to you.
"Thank you for bringing me the news, Watcher, unpleasant though it may be."
"Tell me how to get to Delver's Row, and I'll consider helping you."
"If you do not know your way to the Row, someone at The Hole maybe able to help you."
